section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (block, energy).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What do we learn about where the boy lives?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of spoken language.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Show understanding of the importance of taking care of the planet.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify ways that people can care for their neighborhoods.
Help children use frequently occurring nouns and verbs in their responses.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What buildings do you see in that book?
What can you pretend to do with your neighbors?
How can you sort those toys?
What is your favorite place in your neighborhood? What do you do there?
What materials can you use to make a tree?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word block? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to build a wall? What other materials can you use to make a wall?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder flexible thinking and behavior and introduce vocabulary (ideas, different).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Hey, Wall .
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of spoken language.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Identify own body within surroundings and respects others’ personal space.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children use their flexible thinking skills to look at the same picture in different ways.
Help children use frequently occurring nouns and verbs in their responses.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you name a place that looks like our town?
Pretend you just got a great idea.
Can you draw three people who live near you?
Write about something beautiful in your neighborhood.
Can you draw and color a place in your neighborhood?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word different? Can you write it?
What materials can you use to build a wall like the one in the story?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Prediction and introduce vocabulary (sketches, staring).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What does the boy think about the wall in the beginning of the story?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of spoken language.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children act out different scenes from Hey, Wall .
Encourage children to dance to different musical styles.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the buildings in those books the same? Different?
Can you show me two things you do at home?
Can you compare the size of two buildings? Which is bigger?
Can you write about why the boy wants to change the wall?
Draw a store from your town. What colors will you use to color it?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word wall?
The neighbors used ladders to paint the wall. Can you build a ladder? What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hey, Wall by Susan Verde, illustrated by John Parra. Text copyright © 2018 by Susan Verde. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by John Parra. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Our Neighborhood

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary words (post office, library).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Hey, Wall and Our Neighborhood.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, What is it like where we live?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of spoken language.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Conversation: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts. Share ideas and feelings.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify where people are in their neighborhood.
Help children practice subject-verb agreement by asking questions with singular and plural subjects.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think the boy likes the most about his neighborhood?
Pretend you are reading a book in a library.
Draw three things that have different sizes that you would give to a friend.
Write about a place you would like to visit.
Can you make a map of our school?
Can you tell me the sound you hear at the beginning of the word neighborhood?
Can you build a fire station? What will your fire station have?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hey, Wall by Susan Verde, illustrated by John Parra. Text copyright © 2018 by Susan Verde. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by John Parra. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science: Life Science; Earth and Space Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from Hey, Wall and introduce vocabulary (cheer, dizzy).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Hey, Wall and asking, What is life like in a big city?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of spoken language.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used; Show understanding of the importance of taking care of the planet.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is your favorite place to visit in your neighborhood?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about your neighborhood, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be watering a tree that you just planted?
Draw the biggest tree that grows in your neighborhood.
Create a story about a neighborhood.
Can you imagine a beautiful park in a town? What is in the park? Can you draw the park?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word dizzy?
Build a park. Why did you use those materials to make your park? Could you use other materials?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Are aware of where own body is in space and respect personal boundaries.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Are aware of where own body is in space and respect personal boundaries.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Are aware of where own body is in space and respect personal boundaries.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Are aware of where own body is in space and respect personal boundaries.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and planet.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
